title: Protocol for isolation and analysis of the leukemia stem cells in BCR-ABL-driven chronic myelogenous leukemia mice
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Obtain the BCR-ABL-driven CML mice
Timing: ∼3 weeks
Pretreat male donor C57BL/6 mice (6–8 weeks) with 5-fluorouracil (200 mg/kg) via tail vein injection for 5 days.
Collect BM cells and incubate them with cytokines including stem cell factor (SCF, 50 ng/mL), interleukin-3 (IL-3, 6 ng/mL), and IL-6 (6 ng/mL) for 24 h at 37°C in a humidified incubator with 5% CO2.
Transduce BM cells twice with MSCV-BCR-ABL-IRES-GFP retrovirus (1,500 × g, 90 min, 32°C).
Transplant the infected BM cells into sublethally irradiated (550 cGy) female recipient C57BL/6 mice (6–8 weeks) via tail vein injection.
Obtain CML mice at day 14 post transplantation.
Note: For a detailed protocol of retrovirally BCR-ABL-driven CML mouse model, please refer to Gavrilescu and Van Etten2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]; Zhang and Li.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Generating cell suspension
Timing: 3 h/mouse
In this part, we describe our approaches to harvest BM and splenic cells from CML mice.
Note: In order to keep cells sterile for further sorting, we usually work in a biosafety cabinet and use sterile reagents.
Sacrifice CML mice by cervical dislocation or other approved method.

Figure 1. The percentage of GFP+ cells in PB of a representative CML mouse at day 14 post transplantation
Note: Typically, the percentage of leukemia cells (GFP+) in peripheral blood (PB) from CML mice is more than 50% at day 14 post transplantation (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Harvest splenic cells.
Note: We recommend working on ice during the following steps.
Snip the skin over the midsection using scissors and tweezers (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2490-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Harvest splenic cells from CML mice
(A) Expose the spleen.
(B) Isolate the spleen.
(C) Dissociate the spleen and grind it completely on ice.
(D) Collect splenic cell suspension through a 40 μm cell strainer on ice.

Isolate the spleen and place in a sterile 6 cm dish containing BM flush buffer (refer to materials and equipment) (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Cut the spleen into small tissue pieces using scissors. Grind tissue pieces by the plunger of a 1 mL syringe in 6 cm dish (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Add 2 mL of BM flush buffer into the dish, break down the tissue homogenates by pipetting several times with 1 mL pipette tip. Transfer the suspension into a sterile 50 mL tube through a 40 μm cell strainer (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Note: Repeat 2–3 times for step 7d. We recommend working on ice during steps 7b–7d to maintain cell viability.
Harvest BM cells.
Note: We recommend working on ice during the following steps.
Use scissors to snip the skin over hind legs and pull the skin apart using tweezers.
Hold one hind leg via tweezer and cut off the hip joint using scissors.
Transfer it into a sterile 6 cm dish containing 1 mL BM flush buffer.
Repeat the process for the other hind leg (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2490-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Harvest BM cells from CML mice
(A) Isolate hind legs.
(B) Dissect hind leg into femur and tibia on ice.
(C) Flush and collect BM cells through a 40 μm cell strainer on ice.
Remove the adherent muscle from hind legs using scissors. Dissect hind legs into femurs and tibias (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Hold each bone with tweezer.
Insert the needle of a 1 mL syringe containing 1 mL of BM flush buffer into the marrow cavity.
Flush into the sterile 50 mL tube through a 40 μm cell strainer, repeat flush 6 times.
Repeat this procedure for all bones (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Note: Perform step 8c on ice to maintain cell viability.
Remove erythrocytes from BM and splenic cell suspension, respectively.

Centrifuge cells at 800 × g for 10 min.
Discard supernatant, resuspend the cell pellet with 10 mL of erythrocyte lysis buffer (refer to materials and equipment), and incubate on ice for 5 min.
Centrifuge cells at 800 × g for 10 min.
Note: The volume of erythrocyte lysis buffer is dependent on the number of erythrocytes. Increase the volume if necessary.
Discard supernatant, resuspend the cell pellet with 10 mL of PBS.
Centrifuge cells at 800 × g for 10 min.
Discard supernatant, resuspend the splenic cells with 5 mL of 0.5% BSA buffer and BM cells with 1 mL of 0.5% BSA buffer (refer to materials and equipment), respectively.
Enrichment of GFP+c-Kit+ cells
Timing: 3 h 30 min
In this part of the protocol, we describe how to isolate the GFP+c-Kit+ cells from the BM and splenic cell suspensions obtained in the previous steps. We firstly sorted the GFP+ population from BM and splenic cells using flow cytometer. We then isolated c-Kit+ population from the sorted GFP+ cells using a CD117 Microbeads Kit (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-091-224) according to manufacturer’s instructions. (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/HK-en/products/cd117-microbeads-mouse.html[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/HK-en/products/cd117-microbeads-mouse.html]).
Note: Sterile conditions is necessary if GFP+c-Kit+ cells will be used for culture, colony-forming cell/replating (CFC/replating) assay, and BM transplantation into recipient mice.
Sort GFP+ cells from BM and splenic cell suspension.
Filter the cell suspension through a 40 μm cell strainer in order to remove clumps.
Count the cells and prepare a suspension of 1 × 107 cells/mL of 0.5% BSA buffer in a falcon tube. Keep the samples on ice until cell sorting.
Prepare a 15 mL tube containing 1 mL of 0.5% BSA buffer and 10 μL penicillin/streptomycin solution to collect the sorted cell populations. Keep all the tubes, solutions and sorted cells on ice during sorting process to maintain cell viability.

Perform cell sorting on a BD FACS Aria Ⅱ containing 407/488/633 lasers and use a 100 μm nozzle with a sorting speed of 6,000–8,000 events/second.
Use the BM or splenic cells from normal mice for negative control to set appropriate photomultiplier tubes (PMT) voltages and gating strategy.
According to the gating strategy (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]), sort GFP+ cells by flow cytometry into tubes and transfer onto ice.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2490-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. The purity of the sorted GFP+ cells using flow cytometry is shown
Analyze the percentage of GFP+ cells in the sorted population by flow cytometry (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
Note: It can be obtained approximately 1 × 107 of GFP+ cells from one CML mouse. The users require previous experience with flow cytometry to design the panel.
Enrichment of c-Kit+ population from the sorted GFP+ cells.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 800 × g for 10 min. Aspirate supernatant completely.
Add 500 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer and count the cells.
Place 107 cells in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 300 × g for 10 min. Aspirate supernatant completely.
Resuspend cell pellet with 80 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer and add 20 μL of CD117 microbeads per 107 cells.
Mix well and incubate on ice for 15 min.
Wash the cells with 1 mL of 0.5% BSA buffer, then centrifuge at 300 × g for 10 min. Aspirate supernatant completely.
Resuspend the cell pellet with 50 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer.
Set up the MS column against the magnetic MACS™ Multistand and place a 15 mL tube under the MS column to collect c-Kit- cells.
Add 500 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer to rinse the column.
Note: Always wait until the column is empty before adding cell suspension or buffer.

Add cell suspension into the column, collect the buffer containing unlabeled (GFP+c-Kit-) cells to a 15 mL tube. Wash column with 500 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2490-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Enrichment of c-Kit+ population using a CD117 Microbeads Kit
(A) Collect the unlabeled c-Kit- cells.
(B) Collect the c-Kit+ cells.
Remove the column from the separator, add 500 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer to the column and immediately flush out the labeled c-Kit+ cells to a new 15 mL tube (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Note: This fraction contains GFP+c-Kit+ cells.
Determine the purity of sorted c-Kit+ cells by flow cytometry.
Count the cells, and use 106 cells/sample for antibody staining.
Centrifuge the cells at 800 × g for 5 min.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 100 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer and add 0.5 μL of isotype control (BioLegend, cat#565363) or c-Kit-PE antibody (eBioscience, cat#553355) at 4°C in dark for 30 min.
Add 1 mL of 0.5% BSA buffer, then centrifuge the cells at 800 × g for 5 min.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 400 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer.
Before acquiring samples, set appropriate PMT voltages and compensation by using isotype control.
Analyze the percentage of c-Kit+ cells by flow cytometry (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2490-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. The purity of the sorted GFP+c-Kit+ cells is shown
Determine the function of sorted GFP+c-Kit+ cells by CFC/replating assay.
Count the sorted GFP+c-Kit- and GFP+c-Kit+ cells.
Place 25,000 cells in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge the cells at 800 × g for 5 min.
For a quadruplicate assay, resuspend the cell pellet in 50 μL of PBS and add to 450 μL of MethoCult M3434.
Vortex the tube vigorously to mix the contents thoroughly.

Let the tube stand for at least 5 min to allow the bubbles to rise to the top.
Attach a sterile 16 gauge blunt-end needle to a sterile 1 mL syringe.
Draw up the MethoCult mixture containing cells into the syringe and dispense a volume of 100 μL into individual wells of a 96-well plate (5,000 cells/well).
Incubate at 37°C, in 5% CO2 with ≥ 95% humidity.
After 7 days, count all the colonies in each well using microscope.
Using a 1 mL pipettor, add 200 μL of PBS to each well.
Pipette up and down gently to mix the methylcellulose-based medium with the cells.
Transfer the diluted methylcellulose and the cells into a 4 mL Eppendorf tube.
Note: Repeat 3 times for steps 13k–13m.
Add an additional 2 mL PBS to the tube to ensure that the methylcellulose is completely diluted.
Centrifuge the cells at 800 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant. Resuspend the cell pellet with 1 mL of PBS.
Repeat steps 13a–13j (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2490-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. CFC/replating assay
GFP+c-Kit+ and GFP+c-Kit- cells (5,000 cells/well) sorted from the primary CML mice were plated in methylcellulose medium (MethoCult™ M3434, STEMCELL Technologies) for 3 rounds of replating assay. Colonies were counted on day 7 as described previously.
(A) Representative photographs of colonies from each group. Scale bar: 100 μm.
(B) Quantitative analysis of the colonies is shown. Data are represented as mean ± SEM. ∗∗p < 0.01, ∗∗∗∗p < 0.0001, Student’s t test.
Immunostaining of BM or splenic cells for flow cytometry analysis
Timing: 2 h 30 min

Note: In this procedure, we label BM or splenic cells with the relevant antibodies to analyze the leukemia stem/progenitor cells (Tables 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] and 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]), and myeloid leukemia cells (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]) by flow cytometry. The volume of antibodies depends on the number of cells.

Centrifuge the BM or splenic cell suspension obtained in the previous steps at 800 × g for 10 min, aspirate the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 100 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer.
Stain 106 cells/sample at 4°C in dark for 30 min using different anti-mouse antibodies combined with fluorophore listed in key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Note: It’s important to titrate the antibody to determine the optimal concentration of the antibody before proceeding.
The antibody dilutions in this table are titrated for staining in a volume of 100 μL. The final concentration of the antibodies is listed in the table below.
Add 1 mL of 0.5% BSA buffer to the sample and centrifuge at 800 × g for 10 min, aspirate the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 400 μL of 0.5% BSA buffer. The samples are now ready for analysis by flow cytometry.
Before acquiring samples, set appropriate PMT voltages and compensation by using unstained or single-stained controls (BM or splenic cells from CML mice) for every fluorochrome used in your panel. Adjust compensation using the same set of antibodies.
Define the gating strategy.
Collect data with BD LSRFortessa flow cytometry (BD Biosciences) (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).

(A) Leukemia stem cells, including GFP+LSK cells (GFP+Lin−Sca-1+c-Kit+), GFP+LT-HSCs (GFP+LSK Flt3−CD150+CD48−), GFP+ST-HSCs (GFP+LSK Flt3−CD150−CD48−).
